title: Grateful Dead Live at Rich Stadium on 1986-07-04
lineage: Transfer; Master Cassettes (Nakamichi 700 MKii) > Oade modified Grace Design Lunatec V3 > M-Audio MicroTrack II > WAV 24/96
description:
Set I
Jack Straw
Dupree's Diamond Blues
C.C. Rider
Tennessee Jed
My Brother Esau
Touch Of Grey
Set II
Cold Rain & Snow >
Fire On The Mountain >
Samson & Delilah > *
The Wheel > *
I Need A Miracle > *
Uncle John's Band > *
Drums > *
Space
Gimme Some Lovin' >
Goin' Down The Road Feeling Bad >
Turn On Your Lovelight

Encore:
U.S. Blues


Comment
Bob Dylan and Tom Petty & The Heartbreakers opened
Broadcast on TV for Farm Aid *

Jerry Garcia - Guitar
Bob Weir - Guitar
Brent Mydland - Keyboards
Phil Lesh - Bass
Bill Kreutzmann - Drums
Mickey Hart - Drums

reviews.review_text:
Great pull and, to the taper... ...first, kudos on a spectacular recording. Second, I was there and remember someone with a bandana, without a shirt, a mustache and shades turning around and shushing me during the Dylan/Petty set every time I screamed. Thought that was really strange at a rock concert. Later on I remembered he was standing next to a crutch with another bandana wrapped around the top, which by then I realized must have been hiding a mic pair. If that was you, sorry. I didn't know anything about the taping scene at the time other than it existed. Even now, after nearly fifteen years of taping with my own mics, I'm still ambivalent about taping bands that don't allow it. And I don't shush people unless they're screaming right next to my mics. But whoever that taper was, he was recording history and I've probably listened to his recording since then, and am grateful. 

Thank you for this awesome recording, and braving security and doing what had to be done to get it to us!

The Dead opened for Dylan/Petty Small correction to the notes... The Grateful Dead opened this one. Dylan/Petty played second. 

Thanks for the recording. Difficult conditions to pull a good tape. This sounds pretty decent.

All American Dead 7/4/86

That the band are fish out of water is evident on this soundboard when Bob and Phil wonder who it was that just gave them some instruction or command.  It must have been someone associated with television production because the Dead found themselves being filmed for a national audience as part of Farm Aid at this show in Buffalo.  Phil has also noticed the cameras and has decided to reprise his role as sardonic emcee from the early 70’s.      It was the 4th of July.  It was hot, there were more non-deadheads at this show (and particularly FOB) than I remember at any other show I’ve attended.  I almost didn’t make this one.  

Today, I wonder why I didn’t just hop on the train and go to the DC shows but I jumped at the chance to see them on July 4th, thinking it would be the ultimate American experience.  I had very very high expectations for this show but suddenly, with only a few days to go before it, my car died.  As I was under 25 at the time, I was to learn about the only negative thing about being under 25 was that you could not rent a car.  Did my long-suffering folks want to rent one for me so that my friends and I could drive nine hours across another state to a Grateful Dead show especially when they were beginning to strongly suspect that the “hash” I had been overheard talking about did not involve a recipe for corned beef leftovers.

Somehow, my friend conned his mother into agreeing to do this as long as only he drove.  As always, we hit the rode the day before the show having arranged no lodging when we got to the end of it.  It always worked out before but not this time.  This show was jammed and every hotel was booked except one, which we finally found after midnight.  They could get us into a room for that night only. Damn. Well…that’s fine. We’ll just drive to Greece NY after the show where we stayed during the Rochester shows (as if between Buffalo and Rochester there is only lodging in Greece.  

One thing that kind of sucked was that it was a 2:00 start time for the show and so we did not get a lot of sleep that night.  Oh well.  I remember being blown away that the bills played in the middle of a suburban neighborhood like the late, lost PawSox of Rhode Island.  Big blue stadium.  There’s OJ’s number.  Cool.  The Juice.  The Dead come out inexplicably in the middle of this sunny afternoon, too soon almost and inauspiciously have equipment problems for a few minutes.  The Jack Straw is a little disjointed, probably the worst one in a year that had some truly unique versions of this song.  I was thinking of my friend who was in the hospital and had to miss the show during the next song, which he hates.  Still, it’s a serviceable version of Duprees.  That’s the thing overall with this show.  They more or less just play the songs straight and there’s little to write home about.  It’s kind of a mediocre and very brief show.  Brother Esau is the song that has to suffice as the “jam” of the first set and the Touch closer is pretty sloppy.  

The storm clouds rolled in quickly and the wind began to whip as the band hit the stage for set 2, giving it almost the illusion of being at night finally.  A little rain but mostly wind accompanied Cold Rain and Snow and just as Jerry surprised the band (this is clear in the video) by going into Fire on the Mountain, the sun burst through the clouds as if on command, which of course, it was.  This part of the show was exciting and for the most part, competent.  Samson is more like the first set in its lack of dynamics and it kind of just passes by. Then things get weird as the Grateful Dead are thrust into the living rooms of the Heartland and Bob murkily introduces The Wheel with a metaphorical caution about the importance of crop rotation and a spacey and rare pre-Drums Wheel ensues.  An almost as rare pre-drums Miracle follows and the Fourth is celebrated in style with a rousing Uncle John’s Band.  The set declines swiftly from there as the Gimme Some Lovin’ more or less falls apart and the rest is unmemorable even though I just listened to it yesterday.  

As a postscript, I have to admit that this was both the first of what would become many Bob Dylan shows but it was also, to my shame, the first concert I left early.  Here’s why.  In between the Dead’s way-too-short show and the Dylan/Petty part, there was a lengthy delay of at least 90 minutes.  During this time, the soundboard folks decided to play The Wall, which in the state of mind and given the timing of the dosage per se, I found wicked heavy and depressing and overly self-absorbed and dark.  By the time Dylan came on, I was in no mood for some of the showmanship and posturing of a real rock concert.  And Dylan came across to me as rushing through all the acoustic stuff and overdoing it with hard hard strumming, doing way too many of his overproduced, 80’s numbers and songs I was too ignorant to know at the time (the great “So Long Good Luck and Goodbye” opener, for instance) and shouting instead of singing.  What did I know?  However, I did know this.  I had no interest in seeing Tom Petty mime sorrow in Breakdown, pretend to actually break down and then tell us it’s because the subject of the song “cheated”.  Yuck.  I failed the acid test at that moment and after suffering through the breakneck strumming of the acoustic set, my friends and I decided to start heading toward that motel in Greece we knew would not be filled, the awesome Ground Round just down the road past the Steak and Cake (which we always snubbed after Rochester shows) and to the motel t.v where we knew we would get to watch that weird preacher who seemed to be on all day and all night and who didn’t preach so much as rant and scold.  By 10 PM, we were well into a 12 pack of Miller High Life and the Dr. Gene Scott show.
